text: make it valuable to the reader by sharing 40 years of wisdom. Lessons learned. Maybe a few  stories with a real lesson that people can apply today. And all your social links back to the different stories.. I am not sure who your target audience is.. but you can tailor it however. Another angle to avoid being ego-centered is to  highlight great customers over the 40 years instead of the actual company...  find their stories. good luck

text: We're developing a HARO alternative and I'm looking to conduct a few interviews this week with writers who use HARO to create content (versus being a source). Interviews are for a business course I'm taking around "Business Model Canvas" (core premise of course: interview customers, listen, listen, listen, and then develop). If you have 15 minutes this week, I'd very much appreciate connecting to ask a few questions and share a few features for feedback. Here's a link to my calendar if you'd like to schedule a time: <http://calendly.com/terkel|calendly.com/terkel> (note: only 30 minute slots are available...I'll look to make these interviews 15 minutes). Thanks y'all, and enjoy the week.

text:
Just finished 12 meetings with over 100 B2B SaaS CEOs. 

I always knew that content marketing had the massive potential but listening to first hand accounts of how it changed the face of companies was downright energising!

Here are 5 trends I noticed- 
1. Founders, now more than ever, are looking to build personal brands through content and integrate these with company brands. 
Brands like GetAccept are successfully getting all of their employees to build personal brands to increase brand visibility.

2. CEOs understand the value of authenticity and are excited to put themselves forward - accents, pronunciation errors and grammar mistakes intact. More and more busy CEOs are setting aside *hours* each week to create content.

3. Automation and repurposing of content are important agendas. 

Sample use cases: >Webinars repurposed as video clips, blog posts, social media copy. 

( I do this for some top SaaS brands)


4. Podcasts and videos are now a way to bring your customer forward. Sales reps, founders and marketers need customers to tell other customers about their product.

5. CEOs are happy to hire partners to storify their thoughts and ideas — whether it’s through videos, blogs or interviews.

2. CEOs understand the value of authenticity and are excited to put themselves forward - accents, pronunciation errors and grammar mistakes intact. More and more busy CEOs are setting aside *hours* each week to create content.
3. Automation and repurposing of content are important agendas.
Sample use cases: >Webinars repurposed as video clips, blog posts, social media copy.

text:
I'm working for a B2B client ramping up its thought leadership from its 4 co-founders. Our writers are fantastic, but so far their ghostwriting work has missed the mark in representing a founder's voice and story in an authentic way.

My question to you: *How have you onboarded a writer to someone's voice and perspective they'll be ghostwriting for?*

I'm thinking of hosting a training session, to start. The founders will share their stories, we can discuss how to speak to certain details, etc.

text:
Hi wonderful people. I'm finishing up edits on a book I'm writing called "Writing for Humans and Robots: The New Rules of Content Style" and am getting so in the weeds that I'm starting to second guess myself.

Does this passage make sense? Trying to explain how the buyer's journey and the concept of sales funnels are different but similar and am not sure if I hit the nail on the head:

```"The main difference between the buyer's journey and the sales funnel is that the buyer's journey describes the full process of making a purchase. In contrast, the sales funnel describes the part of the process where a specific company's sales and marketing efforts influence the buyer's decision. You can think of them as running parallel to each other, with the sales funnel representing a focused subsection of the buyer's journey."```

In contrast, the sales funnel describes the part of the process where a specific company's sales and marketing efforts influence the buyer's decision. You can think of them as running parallel to each other, with the sales funnel representing a focused subsection of the buyer's journey."

text:
Unfortunately I’ve found that matching a brand’s voice is WAY different than matching a PERSON’s voice. There’s a lot of study of the person’s natural tone and vocabulary that needs to be done.

Our marketing team is ghostwriting the content for of our exec’s LI feeds, but despite 4 separate in-house marketers (all great writers) attempting it, we’ve never been able to perfectly match our exec’s voice. And this is includes people who’ve known the exec from the start of the company

text:
We're doing more and more of what I would consider product-led at ERIKS. Which can definitely be classified as an enterprise :sweat_smile:.
Here's one on food safe hoses, <https://eriks.nl/nl/know-how-hub/blogs/voedselveiligheid-slangen/|https://eriks.nl/nl/know-how-hub/blogs/voedselveiligheid-slangen/>
And one on food safe seals, <https://eriks.nl/nl/know-how-hub/blogs/voedselveilige-afdichtingen-o-ringen/|https://eriks.nl/nl/know-how-hub/blogs/voedselveilige-afdichtingen-o-ringen/>
Both in Dutch, still working on translations for our corporate portal.

The product is quite front and center. So far it works quite well in terms of engagement. Still need to optimize it for (micro) conversions though

text:
What are some seriously awesome glossary sites in terms of UX that you all know of?

I’m currently working with my team to build out a technical glossary, and I’d love some inspiration. What are some sites you see really going above and beyond to create a great experience for the visitor instead of just solely spitting out a definition at you? If you can’t think of any examples, how might you think about creating a unique experience for something typically a pretty cut & dry experience?

text: <@U02Q67WK4LS> I don’t work exclusively as a ghostwriter, but I’ve done it for several execs, both as an in-house marketer and a freelance writer. The things that I find most helpful are: 1) listening to the exec speak about the thought leadership topic, whether that’s in a live interview , a voice memo, or as a recorded Zoom session with 2-3 stakeholders discussing the topic; 2) seeing successful examples of the exec’s thought leadership content. For 1), it helps me to hear them talk about the topic in a conversational way—how they use industry lingo, what verbs and adjectives they repeat, what specific examples they speak to to support their ideas, and how they inject humor or lightheartedness into a serious topic. For 2), it helps me understand what the exec is shooting for. Sometimes the voice they want to convey in written thought leadership isn’t actually all that similar to how they talk—which IMHO isn’t a good thing, but when you’re ghostwriting, sometimes you just need to make the client happy. And sometimes that means making them sound smarter, more articulate, or more inspired than they sound in person. (In this scenario, if the exec doesn’t have any examples of thought leadership that they’re already happy with, having them share 2-3 examples from different writers whose voice they admire or want to emulate can also help get you there.) For me, the combination of conversational recording and written examples helps me get to a place where execs are happy with the results, feel well-represented, and are proud to publish much faster. Good luck!!

For 1), it helps me to hear them talk about the topic in a conversational way—how they use industry lingo, what verbs and adjectives they repeat, what specific examples they speak to to support their ideas, and how they inject humor or lightheartedness into a serious topic. For 2), it helps me understand what the exec is shooting for. Sometimes the voice they want to convey in written thought leadership isn’t actually all that similar to how they talk—which IMHO isn’t a good thing, but when you’re ghostwriting, sometimes you just need to make the client happy. And sometimes that means making them sound smarter, more articulate, or more inspired than they sound in person. (In this scenario, if the exec doesn’t have any examples of thought leadership that they’re already happy with, having them share 2-3 examples from different writers whose voice they admire or want to emulate can also help get you there.) For me, the combination of conversational recording and written examples helps me get to a place where execs are happy with the results, feel well-represented, and are proud to publish much faster. Good luck!!

text: Having also ghost written for the CEO, I can say I don't think having a personal relationship with the exec is important at all, nor is hearing how they converse in the real world, such as on a zoom meeting. Similar to Sara, I learned by listening to the CEO's podcasts and reading a lot of her long form content. It's all about hearing how they talk/seeing how they write about a topic at length. But that's. my experience for long-form writing, I bet for short-form social content writing, short convos and shorter form examples would be fine.

I think it's good <@U01NM31CTFU>. There are still debates on "when" a buying journey begins (I fall into the Jobs-To-Be-Done camp of First thought) and IMHO, I think you can start influencing a decision before a sale.

But ATEOTD day I think what you wrote holds true.
